Various | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = | notable_instruments = }} '''Walter Horton''', better known as '''Big Walter Horton''' or '''Walter "Shakey" Horton''', (April 6, 1918 – December 8, 1981{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p373/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Steve Huey |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=May 30, 2009}})Eagle and LeBlanc, "Blues: A Regional Experience," p. 193. According to the authors, the 1921 date comes directly from information obtained via Horton's birth certificate. was an American [[blues]] harmonica player. A quiet, unassuming and essentially shy man, Horton is remembered as one of the premier harmonica players in the history of blues. [[Willie Dixon]] once called Horton "the best harmonica player I ever heard." ==Biography== Born '''Walter Horton''' in [[Horn Lake, Mississippi]], he was playing a harmonica by the time he was five years old. In his early teens, he lived in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] and claimed that his earliest recordings were done there in the late 1920s with the [[Memphis Jug Band]], although there is no documentation of it, and some blues researchers have stated that this story was most likely fabricated by Horton. (He also claimed to have taught some harmonica to [[Little Walter]] and the original [[Sonny Boy Williamson I|Sonny Boy Williamson]], although these claims are unsubstantiated, and in the case of the older Williamson, somewhat suspect). As with many of his peers, he spent much of his career existing on a meager income and living with constant discrimination in a segregated United States of America. In the 1930s he played with various blues performers across the [[Mississippi delta]] region. It is generally accepted that his first recordings were made in Memphis backing guitarist [[Little Buddy Doyle]] on Doyle's recordings for the [[Okeh Records|Okeh]] and [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] labels in 1939.Note: According to Dixon and Godrich ("Recording the Blues," p. 92), the ARC/Vocalion company files list Hammie Nixon as the harmonica player, not Horton. These recordings were in the acoustic duo format popularized by [[Sleepy John Estes]] with his harmonicist [[Hammie Nixon]], among others. On these recordings, Horton's style is not yet fully realized, but there are clear hints of what is to come. He eventually stopped playing the harp for a living due to poor health, and worked mainly outside of the music industry in the 1940s. By the early 1950s, he was playing music again, and was among the first to record for [[Sam Phillips]] at [[Sun Records]] in Memphis, who would later record [[Elvis Presley]], [[Carl Perkins]], and [[Johnny Cash]]. The early Big Walter recordings from Sun include performances from a young [[Phineas Newborn, Jr.]] on piano, who later gained fame as a [[jazz]] pianist. His instrumental track recorded around this time, "Easy", was based on [[Ivory Joe Hunter]]'s "[[I Almost Lost My Mind]]".{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 118–119 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}{{cite web |url= http://www.filisko.com/assets/Walter%20Horton%20Discography.PDF|title= Walter Horton's Recordings|first= Joe|last= Filisko |date= December 9, 2009|work= |publisher= |format= PDF|accessdate=January 16, 2010}} During the early 1950s he first appeared on the [[Chicago blues]] scene, where he frequently played with fellow Memphis and Delta musicians who had also moved north, including guitarists [[Eddie Taylor]] and [[Johnny Shines]]. When [[Junior Wells]] left the [[Muddy Waters]] band at the end of 1952, Horton replaced him for long enough to play on one session with Waters in January 1953. Also known as "Mumbles" and "Shakey" because of his head motion while playing the harmonica, Horton was active on the Chicago blues scene during the 1960s as blues music gained popularity with white audiences. From the early 1960s onward, he recorded and appeared frequently as a sideman with [[Eddie Taylor]], Johnny Shines, Johnny Young, [[Sunnyland Slim]], Willie Dixon and many others. He toured extensively, usually as a backing musician, and in the 1970s he performed at blues and folk music festivals in the U.S. and Europe, frequently with Willie Dixon's Chicago Blues All-Stars. He has also appeared as a guest on recordings by blues and rock stars such as [[Fleetwood Mac]] and [[Johnny Winter]]. In October 1968, while touring the United Kingdom, he recorded the album ''Southern Comfort'' with the former [[Savoy Brown]] and future [[Mighty Baby]] guitarist [[Martin Stone (guitarist)|Martin Stone]]. In the late 1970s he toured the U.S. with [[Homesick James Williamson]], Guido Sinclair, [[Eddie Taylor]], [[Richard Molina]], [[Bradley Pierce Smith]] and [[Paul Nebenzahl]], and appeared on [[National Public Radio]] broadcasts. Two of the best compilation albums of his own work are ''Mouth-Harp Maestro'' and ''Fine Cuts''. Also notable is the ''Big Walter Horton and [[Carey Bell]]'' album, released by [[Alligator Records]] in 1972. He worked at blues festivals, and was often seen giving free shows at the [[Maxwell Street]] market inChicago. In 1977, he worked on the Muddy Waters album ''[[I'm Ready (Muddy Waters album)|I'm Ready]]'', produced by Johnny Winter. He also recorded for [[Blind Pig Records]] during this period. Horton accompanied [[John Lee Hooker]] in the 1980 film ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]''. His final recordings were made in 1980. Horton died from heart failure in Chicago in 1981 at the age of 60,Eagle and LeBlanc, p. 193. and was buried in [[Restvale Cemetery]] in [[Alsip, Illinois]]. He was posthumously inducted into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]] in 1982. ==Discography== {{expand section|date=September 2012}} *''The Soul of Blues Harmonica'' (Argo, 1964) *''Big Walter Horton with Carey Bell'' (Alligator Records, 1972) *''Walter Shakey Horton with Hot Cottage'' (Stony Plain Records, 1974) ==See also== *[[List of blues musicians]] *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] *[[List of juke joint blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonica blues musicians]] *[[List of Memphis blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonicists]] *[[List of people from Mississippi]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bluesharp.ca/legends/bwalter.html Horton biography by Michael Erlewine] {{Authority control|VIAF=54334985}} {{Persondata | NAME =Horton, Walter | ALTERNATIVE NAMES =Big Walter Horton, Shaky Horton | SHORT DESCRIPTION =American blues harmonica player | DATE OF BIRTH =April 6, 1917 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Horn Lake, Mississippi]], United States | DATE OF DEATH =December 8, 1981 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Horton, Big Walter}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:African-American musicians]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Blues Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Juke Joint blues musicians]] [[Category:Chess Records artists]] [[Category:Deaths from heart failure]] [[Category:Okeh Records artists]] [[Category:Sun Records artists]] [[Category:Vanguard Records artists]] [[Category:Columbia Records artists]]
